content: Shares of General Mills (GIS) sank Wednesday after the Cheerios and Yoplait maker delivered mixed results and lowered its growth outlook citing significant cost headwinds.General Mills' dive spread contagion through the packaged food sector, taking down shares of Kellogg (K), Kraft Heinz (KHC), Campbell Soup (CPB), J.M. Smucker Co. (SJM), ConAgra (CAG) and Mondelez (MDLZ). Kraft Heinz and Campbell Soup hit the sector last month on their weak quarterly reports.Shares of General Mills plunged 8.85% to 45.51 on the stock market today, hitting their lowest level in nearly five years. General Mills is by far the worst-performing stock on the S&P 500 index.They have tumbled since their Jan. 25 high of 60.69. Kellogg crashed 4%. Kraft Heinz lost 1.9%, hitting its worst levels since August 2015, while Campbell Soup sank 2.2%, reaching a 4-year low. Mondelez slid 0.8% and J.M. Smucker retreated 4.2%.Kellogg, J.M. Smucker, Campbell Soup and ConAgra all were among the S&P 500 index's worst-performers.The Minneapolis-based company reported adjusted quarterly profit grew 10% to 79 cents per share, meeting the Zacks Investment Research consensus estimate. Revenue ticked up 2% to $3.88 billion, just short of views for $3.89 billion. Organic net sales — stripping out the effect of currency movements, acquisitions and divestitures — were up 1%.Cost pressures are impacting the full-year outlook, said General Mills Chairman and CEO Jeff Harmening. General Mills cut its adjusted earnings growth forecast to flat to up 1% from up 3% to 4% earlier.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"Like the broader industry, we're seeing sharp increases in input costs, including inflation in freight and commodities," Harmening added. "Because of our improved volume performance, we're also incurring higher operational costs."Net sales for the North America retail segment rose 1% to $2.52 billion, thanks in large part to Canada. Yogurt and cereal sales fell in the U.S.Sales in the convenience stores and food service segment rose 3% to $460 million, driven by growth in frozen meals, cereal, and snacks.Europe and Australia sales grew 11% to $470 million, benefiting from favorable currency moves. Organic net sales slipped 1%.Asia and Latin America sales increased 3% to $435 million, also helped by foreign currency exchange. Organic net sales matched year-ago levels.  Asia markets saw higher sales, offsetting lower net sales across Latin America.General Mills said Wednesday its previously announced $8 billion acquisition of natural pet food brand Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) is expected to close before the end of fiscal 2018. Natural, wholesome and premium fare is in demand in pet food, as in human food, according to General Mills.Packaged food is under strain as private-label house brands as well as organic and natural offerings displace mainstream products on grocery shelves at the likes of Walmart (WMT) and Kroger (KR) and Amazon (AMZN)-owned Whole Foods.Walmart is General Mills' biggest customer, accounting for some 20% of sales.Packaged food companies have responded with cost cuts, including on marketing, to preserve profit margins, but that strategy is running out of steam. Kraft Heinz's latest results show the cost-cutting strategy is running out of steam.Blue Buffalo shares edged 0.3% lower Wednesday. Walmart rose 0.3%, Amazon dipped 0.3%. and Kroger added 0.2%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Forget Facebook: Why These 5 Chip Stocks Are Stock Market Bullish; S&P 500, Dow Jones Futures Await Fed Rate HikeThe Big Picture: Stock Bounce Leaves Much To Be DesiredNo. 1-Ranked IPO Stock Breaks Out, Expects Big Q1 Earnings GrowthThese 5 Top Stocks Stood Out MondayThese 3 China Nets Are Flashing This Bullish Signal; This 1 Has Earnings Due'China's Amazon' JD.com Has These Futuristic Projects In The Works

On Wednesday, Flowers Foods (FLO) earned a positive adjustment to its Relative Strength (RS) Rating, from 66 to 71. X When looking for the best stocks to buy and watch, one factor to watch closely is relative price strength.This exclusive rating from Investor's Business Daily identifies market leadership with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The score shows how a stock's price performance over the trailing 52 weeks stacks up against all the other stocks in our database. History reveals that the market's biggest winners tend to have an RS Rating north of 80 as they begin their largest climbs. See if Flowers Foods can continue to rebound and hit that benchmark. See if the stock forms a new chart pattern or follow-on buying opportunity like a three-weeks tight or pullback to the 50-day or 10-week moving average. Flowers Foods reported 0% EPS growth in its most recent report, while sales growth came in at 1%. Flowers Foods holds the No. 8 rank among its peers in the Food-Packaged industry group. Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF), Snyders-Lance (LNCE) and JM Smucker (SJM) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.RELATED:Which Stocks Are Showing Improved Technical Action?Why Should You Use IBD's Relative Strength Rating?How Relative Strength Line Can Help You Judge A Stock

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Friday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. X Three highly rated companies will lead the earnings charge: IPG Photonics (IPGP), Deere (DE) and VF Corp. (VFC). Meanwhile, a host of food and beverage companies will report as well, including Campbell Soup (CPB), Kraft Heinz (KHC),…

The main stock indexes were modestly lower Thursday afternoon in a session that has lacked any clear direction.XThe Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were down 0.2% after seesaw action all day. While those were minor losses, both indexes have faded back below their 50-day moving averages. Two days ago, a move above those lines helped build a more favorable case for stocks.The Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1% . The Dow is only 1% off its high, even though the average Dow component is nearly 7% below its 52-week high.Only a few of the components have been carrying the weight. UnitedHealth Group (UNH), Procter & Gamble (PG), Visa (V), McDonald's (MCD) and Caterpillar (CAT) are near new highs.Boeing has been a top performer and is now forming a follow-on buy point at 256.59. McDonald's has been rising after pulling back to the 50-day moving average. P&G is near the 92.10 buy point of a base.Small caps managed to climb as the Russell 2000 added 0.2%. Volume was tracking modestly higher compared with the same time yesterday.Food stocks were lower as some companies missed profit expectations.Two of them slid to the lowest levels since October 2015 in heavy volume. J.M. Smucker (SJM) stumbled 8% after the maker of jams, jellies and coffee reported adjusted earnings of $1.51 per share for the July-ended quarter, below views. Sales fell 4% to $ 1.749 billion.The company said the decline was mainly due to lower-than-anticipated volume for Folgers coffee. Smucker said it's changing its strategy and Folgers "volume trends are improving."Hormel Foods (HRL) gapped down to a loss of 5.5% in six times its average volume. The maker of Spam, Jennie-O turkey products, Skippy peanut butter and other supermarket fare missed profit expectations. EPS declined 6% and sales dropped 4% to $2.2 billion.Sanderson Farms (SAFM) reversed lower after hitting a new high. The meat products company topped estimates with a profit of $5.09 a share for the July quarter.In other sectors, Toro (TTC) mowed down its share price by 7% as the stock sank deeper below the 50-day moving average. A breakout from a 73.10 buy point on Aug. 8 has now failed. Shares are 12% below the buy point. The maker of lawn mowers and other yard-care products slid despite beating profit expectations.Dell Technologies (DVMT) rose nearly 1%. The stock is following through after it cleared the 68.25 buy point of a cup with handle this week.RELATED:This Retail Stock May Be Having Its Biggest Day Ever; Others Soar TooApple Is A Buy, But The Dow's Top Stock Finally Has A New Entry Point

Food producers generally had a tough day Thursday as Hormel Foods (HRL) and JM Smucker (SJM) led hefty sell-offs after reporting weak quarterly results. XTwo stocks managing to at least briefly tap out new highs within that trend were Sanderson Farms (SAFM) and Pilgrim's Pride (PPC). Both stocks have been front-runners in the meat products group,…

Stocks opened modestly higher Thursday but turned slightly lower even as many retailers soared on earnings surprises.X The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 erased early gains to dip 0.1%. The Nasdaq also lost 0.1% after briefly retaking its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 continues to contend with resistance just below that line.Economic news Thursday leads off with the start of the international Economic Symposium at Jackson Hole, Wyo., and with the Labor Department reporting jobless claims rose slightly, but held at the low level of 234,000 in the week ended Aug. 19. That was an uptick from the prior week's 232,000 claims, but below economist projections for an increase to 237,000.July existing home sales fell 1.3% to an annual rate of 5.44 million, the Commerce Department said. That was below views for 5.565 million.Apple (AAPL) turned down to fall 0.2%. A CFRA research report late Wednesday argued that estimates for iPhone average sale prices were too low. The stock remains in a buy range above a 156.52 buy point.FANG stocks also gave up early gains. Netflix (NFLX) was flat. Amazon.com (AMZN) lagged, down 1% after news late Thursday that the Federal Trade Commission would allow Amazon.com's (AMZN) merger with grocer Whole Foods Market (WFM). Whole Foods rose 0.7% in early trade.Retailers exerted a strong early influence on the session, with Home Depot (HD), down 0.4%.After each reported quarterly results, Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) soared 13%, Guess (GES) 15%, Dollar Tree (DLTR) 8%, sports apparel chain Tilly's (TLYS) 5% and kitchenware shop Willliams-Sonoma (WSM) nearly 4%.Signet Jewelers (SIG) bolted 20.5% higher after knocking second-quarter expectations out of the park. The big move drove shares back above their 10-week moving average, but the stock reamains deep in a 21-month decline.Burlington Stores (BURL) vaulted 5% in morning action. Its second-quarter earnings soared 39%, well above analyst estimates. Revenue narrowly topped views and management offered strong guidance. The stock has posted five weeks of very tight weekly closes, as it forms a possible bottom to a three-month consolidation.Foods producers were having a tough morning, as Hormel Foods (HRL) stumbled 7% lower and JM Smucker (SJM) dropped nearly 8%. Both companies reported weak quarterly results and served up guidance below consensus targetsAmong IBD 50 stocks, capacitor maker Kemet (KEM) popped 1.5%. Shares are extended, up 37% and in a profit-taking zone after clearing a flat base in July.Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) rose 0.3%. The maker of telecom network gear has been trading in a buy range, just above a 64.72 cup base buy point since a strong-volume breakout on Aug. 3.RELATED: The Big Picture: Breakouts Hold UpApple, Amazon Loom Over Key Earnings Reports: Investing Action PlanStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksInvestor's Corner: Why Fewer Stocks Are Key To Greater Portfolio ReturnsDefense And Aerospace Stocks To Watch And Industry NewsChip Stocks To Watch And Semiconductor Industry News

Kraft Heinz (KHC) indicated that it is still interested in combining with Unilever NV (UN), even after the Anglo-Dutch consumer products giant rebuffed a $50-per-share merger offer reportedly worth $143 billion."Kraft confirms that it has made a comprehensive proposal to Unilever about combining the two groups to create a leading consumer goods company with a mission of long-term growth and sustainable living," Kraft Heinz said in a statement."While Unilever has declined the proposal, we look forward to working to reach agreement on the terms of a transaction."Kraft Heinz shares jumped 10.7% to 96.65 in the stock market today, hitting an all-time high. Kraft had fallen 4.2% on Thursday following its latest earnings report.But Unilever — the parent of brands such as Dove, Vaseline and Q-tips — said that the offer "fundamentally undervalues" the company and provides no financial or strategic merit for Unilever shareholders, according to a statement acquired by Reuters."Unilever does not see the basis for any further discussions," it said.Shares of Unilever NV jumped 15.3% to 48.79, setting an all-time high. Unilever PLC (UL) popped 14% to 48.53, just below a record level.RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer pondered whether "Unilever's focus on sustainability might make it very resistant to any further approach from Kraft," and believes Kraft Heinz "will  likely need to raise its offer substantially if it hopes to change the outcome."According to Bloomberg data, a Kraft Heinz-Unilever would have made for the second-biggest food and beverage company in the world behind Nestle. Kraft Heinz is currently the fifth-largest food and drink conglomerate in the world after Kraft and Heinz merged in 2015.Meanwhile, Mondelez International (MDLZ) shares fell 1.6%. Shares of the Oreo and Nabisco parent shot up 4.4% on Dec. 15 on word that it might be bought out by Kraft Heinz.Last June, Hershey (HSY) rejected a $107-a-share takeover bid from Mondelez.General Mills (GIS) shares lost 3.75%, as the owner of Cheerios and Betty Crocker on Friday cut sales and earnings outlooks. It now sees a 4% organic net sales decline for 2017, "due primarily to a widening gap between the company's level of promotional activity and that of competitors in the U.S. yogurt and soup categories." The stock gapped down to the lowest level in a year.J.M. Smucker (SJM) shares sank 1.4% on a disappointing third-quarter report, missing sales estimates and meeting per-share profit expectations. The company also notched down its outlook, trimming the top end of its profit forecast and lowering sales guidance to a 3% decline vs. prior outlook for a flat-to-1% decline in fiscal 2017. The stock gapped below the 200-day moving average but remains in a long base.Campbell Soup (CPB) shares tumbled 6.5% in heavy trading. The company reaffirmed full-year guidance but turned in mixed results.RELATED:Mondelez Surges On Reports Of Acquisition By Kraft HeinzNot Sweet Enough: Hershey Unanimously Rejects Mondelez Offer

J.M. Smucker (SJM) trimmed its outlook on sales for this year amid predictions that weakness in pet foods will continue through the rest of 2016.The maker of Folgers coffee, Jif peanut butter and Smucker's jams and jellies now sees adjusted 2016 sales to be down 1% or flat, vs. a prior forecast for a 1% increase.Smucker executives told analysts on an earnings call they expects softness in pet food sales to continue through the end of the year.Fiscal Q1 earnings jumped 41% to $1.86 per share, beating estimates for $1.74. Revenue fell 7% to $1.82 billion, below estimates for $1.89 billion.Shares closed down 8.1% at 143.63, diving below their 50-day average, in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Shares broke out from a 132.74 buy point in June and even began closing in on profit-taking range.Specialty pet food maker Blue Buffalo (BUFF) ended virtually flat at 26.29, near a 27.47 buy point. Among makers of packaged food for humans, meanwhile, Kellogg (K) fell 0.4%, Campbell Soup (CPB) dipped 1.4%, ConAgra (CAG) lost 1.7%, and General Mills (GIS) eased 0.6%.IBD'S TAKE: Highly rated J.M. Smucker's sales disappointed Wall Street on weakness in pet food and coffee. The package food sector is consolidating, and shares of some companies have soared recently amid increased M&A activity.Smucker's coffee revenue of $513.3 million in Q1 was down from $565 million a year earlier, in part on weak Dunkin' (DNKN) K-Cup pods sales and lower net prices. Sales of Kibbles 'n Bits, Meow Mix and other pet food  products collectively fell 6% to $519.5 million, in part on difficult comps vs. strong sales of new brands a year before.However, the company expects to achieve $100 million of incremental synergies for the full fiscal year as it consolidates after divestments and recent acquisitions, such as Meow Mix maker Big Heart Pet Brands, which it acquired in March 2015.Smucker maintained it outlook for full-year adjusted EPS of $7.60 to $7.75, the midpoint of which is a little below analysts' consensus for $7.70.

The major averages ended mixed in a nearly flat session Monday, as biotech stocks rose to help offset declines in the oil sector.The Nasdaq edged up 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each dipped 0.1%. Volume fell on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE compared to Friday, according to preliminary data.After the close, Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) plunged 10% following its quarterly earnings report. The fast-casual Mediterranean-style restaurant chain closed the regular trading session 10% off its 52-week high and has been consolidating since early April.Elsewhere in the stock market today, biotech stock Medivation (MDVN) rocketed nearly 20% skyward after Pfizer (PFE) announced plans to buy the maker of cancer drugs for $14 billion. For its own part, Pfizer dipped a fraction.IBD'S TAKE: Want to know how Pfizer stacks up against other stocks in its industry? Find out at IBD's Stock Checkup.The deal news helped boost IBD's biomedical industry group 2%.Amphastar Pharmaceuticals (AMPH) jumped 3% to a new high in heavy volume. The maker of drugs to treat diabetes, asthma and other diseases is out of buying range after clearing a 17.90 buy point of a long, deep cup-with-handle base.Meanwhile, oil producer Denbury Resources (DNR) dropped nearly 6%, leading the S&P 500 lower, as crude prices sank 3%.Dycom (DY), Best Buy (BBY), J.M. Smucker (SJM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Tuesday.Economic data due Tuesday include new-home sales for July.

A five-week rally has put some Big Cap 20 names near buy points. One is Salesforce.com (CRM), which is setting up in a flat base with a 84.58 buy point. It's part of a base-on-base formation, which is normally a powerful launching pad for an advance. Salesforce has a history of breaking out and making only a small advance before…

J.M. Smucker (SJM) reported strong fiscal fourth-quarter earnings and gave upbeat guidance Thursday, driving its stock to a record high.The maker of Folgers brand coffee, Jif peanut butter and its namesake line of jams and jellies reported fiscal fourth-quarter non-GAAP earnings of $1.86 a share, reversing from an 41-cent loss in the same quarter a year earlier. Earnings for the most recent quarter included a deferred tax benefit of 42 cents.Revenue climbed nearly 25% to $1.81 billion from $1.45 billion as coffee sales rose 9% to $512.6 million and pet food sales jumped 135% to $562.9 million, partly on its acquisition of Big Heart Pet Brands for $6 billion last year.Smucker shares leapt 7.9% to 143.23 on the stock market today. The stock blasted past a 132.74 buy point of a flat base.How sweet is J.M. Smucker's stock, and how does it compare to rivals? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupThe company's U.S. Retail Consumer Food sales dipped 2% to $473.7 million after it earlier divested its U.S. canned milk business for an undisclosed sum last year.Smucker projects that sales for the current fiscal year will decrease by 1% due to the sale of the canned milk business, and it expects diluted earnings of $7.60-$7.75 a share, well above estimates for $6.37."We have clear visibility to achieving incremental $100 million in synergies this fiscal year," Chief Executive Mark Smucker said in a written statement.Its stock, which has a strong 85 IBD Composite Rating out of a best possible 99, was on track to close higher for a seventh day in a row. An 85 rating means it's outperformed 85% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.

The market is in a funk. Money managers have their worry beads working over Brexit, an ineffectual Federal Reserve, and fears of European and Asian meltdowns, not to mention a presidential election that could set the course for economic policy for years to come. So it's not surprising the names dominating the Big Cap 20 have a defensive tone. The…

Despite the volatility, it's surprising how many members of the Big Cap 20 list of large-cap growth stocks are extended and at new highs. Most of those have a defensive flavor, such as AT&T (T) and J.M. Smucker (SJM). Both braved the two-day sell-off following the Brexit vote with barely a hiccup, then rocketed to new highs on the recovery…

The market sold off a bit Thursday, but a handful of stocks were propelled to new highs as they basked in the afterglow of well-received earnings reports. Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) gapped up for a better-than-10% gain Wednesday as investors cheered its first-quarter report. They followed through Thursday with more buying as the stock gained 1.58 to close at…

Stocks remained broadly lower in afternoon trading Thursday, though off session lows. Retailers led the downside after a weak earnings report from Restoration Hardware (RH).The Nasdaq fell 0.3% while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.2%. Volume was tracking lower across the board in the stock market today.Losers led winners by more than a 2-to-1 ratio on the NYSE and by a roughly an 8-to-3 ratio on the Nasdaq.Retail and steel stocks were among the worst performers.Restoration Hardware plunged 10% after posting a loss of 5 cents a share in the latest quarter, much worse than expected. Revenue rose 8% to $455.5 million, the weakest growth in years. The luxury home-furnishings retailer also issued a disappointing outlook. The stock is now at its lowest level since its November 2012 IPO.Williams-Sonoma (WSM), another home furnishings retailer, dropped nearly 5%.Food stocks were among the best performers.J.M. Smucker (SJM) soared 7.5% to 142.61 to a new high in heavy volume after the maker of coffee, peanut butter and other products posted a profit of $2.23 a share for the latest quarter, rebounding from a loss of 20 cents in the same quarter a year ago and blowing away Wall Street forecasts. Sales rose 25% to $1.81 billion, continuing a four-quarter stretch of strong revenue gains.The stock cleared a 132.74 buy point of a flat base.Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, but U.S. Concrete (USCR) climbed more than 1% to 64.96 as it works on a new base with a buy point at 69.76.

Stocks held modest losses in early afternoon trading Thursday despite a better-than-expected jobless claims report and notable moves from blue chips Apple (AAPL) and Nike (NKE).The Nasdaq gave up 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were each off 0.2%. Volume continued to track lower across the board vs. the same time Wednesday.In economic news, initial jobless claims fell to 265,000 in the week ended June 4, better than an expected increase to 270,000. The Labor Department also revised the prior week's claims to 268,000 from 267,000.Big losers in the stock market today included retail, steel and telecom stocks. Restoration Hardware (RH) gapped down and plunged more than 20% to a new low in heavy trade after reporting disappointing Q2 results. The furniture retailer also offered weaker-than-expected guidance.On the IBD 50, Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) sank nearly 5% in hefty volume, slipping below a 26.08 cup-with-handle buy point initially cleared May 11. Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, but U.S. Concrete[ticker symb=USCR] added 1% in light trade as it builds a base-on-base pattern.Gold miners, meat processors and other food stocks bucked the decline. Gold prices rose nearly 1% to $1,272.80 an ounce. Among food plays, peanut butter and jam maker J.M. Smucker (SJM) gapped up and soared 7% to a new high after reporting fiscal Q4 results that topped views.Nike led the Dow's few gainers with a 1.4% jump as the stock attempts to come back from a recent decline. Shares are still below their 50-day and 200-day lines and 19% off their 52-week high. Ben Simmons, the projected No.1 NBA draft pick, said Tuesday he has signed an endorsement deal with the athletic shoe and apparel powerhouse. On Wednesday, Nike said it would continue to sponsor tennis star Maria Sharapova despite a two-year ban by the International Tennis Federation for doping.Find out if Nike is the top-rated shoe and apparel maker at IBD Stock Checkup.Apple, the second biggest gainer on the Dow, advanced 1% as it seeks to regain its 50-day moving average. The stock has rebounded 11% from a May 12 low but remains 25% off its 52-week high. Mizuho Securities raised concerns about the iPhone maker's plan to expand into India to offset slowing sales in China and about potential acquisitions, but maintained a buy rating and 120 price target.

Stocks opened lower Thursday, as oil prices, overseas trade and earnings reports weighed.The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell 0.3% at the open.Among the stocks making notable early moves in the stock market today were Restoration Hardware (RH), Apple (AAPL) supplier Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and J.M. Smucker (SJM).Initial jobless claims dipped to 265,000 in the week ended June 4, the Labor Department reported. That was better than the uptick to 270,000 claims economists expected. The department also revised the prior week's claims to 268,000, from 267,000. The four-week moving average eased to 269,500, a second straight decline.April wholesale inventory data are due from the Commerce Department at 10 a.m. ET.Dow stocks traded flat to lower. United Technologies (UTX) was down 0.2%. Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 0.3%.Chipmaker Skyworks Solutions slipped more than 1%. Citigroup downgraded the Apple iPhone supplier to sell, from neutral, and cut its price target to 65 from 69.50. The note cited valuation, shifting markets and Skyworks' dependence on mobile markets.Restoration Hardware traded down more than 18% after its Q1 results -- reported after Wednesday's close -- showed a loss vs. analyst expectations for a profit. Revenue rose more than expected, but Q2 and full-year guidance were far below consensus views. The high-end home furnishings retailer received downgrades from at least four brokerages.Peanut butter and jelly maker J.M. Smucker jumped 5.5% after reporting better-than-expected fiscal Q4 results. The stock ended Wednesday's session pennies below a 132.74 buy point in a flat base.Other, early earnings-related moves included Francesca's Holdings (FRAN), up 3%, ABM Industries (ABM), with a 4% gain and Fuelcell Energy (FCEL), which tumbled 13%.Solar energy installation leader SolarCity (SCTY) climbed more than 3%, after R.W. Baird upgraded the stock to outperform from neutral.China's markets notched narrow losses Thursday, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell 1%. Markets in Europe were also under pressure, with Frankfurt's DAX down hardest, -1.5% entering afternoon trade.Oil slipped more than 1%, with West Texas Intermediate holding above $50 a barrel. Gold dipped to $1,260 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds nudged higher, trimming the 10-year yield 3 basis points to 1.67%.

Here is your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: What you need to know as an investor. Coffee and condiments purveyor J.M. Smucker (SJM), apparel retailer Francesca's (FRAN) and tax-assistance provider H&R Block (HRB) all report results. J.M. Smucker Wall Street expects J.M. Smucker, whose brands include Smucker's, Folgers and Pillsbury, to report fourth-quarter sales growth of 20.5% to $1.744 billion. Earnings per share…

J.M. Smucker (SJM) said Tuesday that it is cutting the list price of most of its packaged coffee products by an average of 6% "in response to sustained declines in green coffee costs," marking the second time in the last 12 months that the company has slapped a lower price tag on its products.The parent of Folgers coffee, Smucker announced price cuts last July as well, also reducing prices by an average of 6%. Smucker licenses Dunkin' Donuts brand coffees, which was included in both price cuts. But Smucker-licensed K-Cups were not included in either of the decreases.Smucker shares closed up 0.8% in the stock market today. Shares of the company, whose brands also include Smucker's, Crisco and Milk-Bone, hit a new intraday high of 132.64 on April 1 and have since been forming a flat base with 132.74 entry point. The stock is still below its 50-day line. Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) rose 1.2%.Starbucks (SBUX), meanwhile, hiked the prices of some of its in-store drink menu last July by 5 cents to 20 cents, citing rent and labor costs. That increase did not affect packaged coffee.Shares of Starbucks added 1.5%.RELATED:Smucker, Marsh Hit New Highs, But Can’t Finish Breakout.

B&G Foods (BGS), a member of Thursday’s Stock Spotlight screen, might be a lesser-known name IBD's Food-Products group, but it boasts a nice yield, a sound chart and outstanding fundamentals and a sound chart. Big sales in the past two quarters is a result of its $765 million acquisition last year of the Green Giant business from General Mills (GIS).…

The upcoming week of earnings reports isn’t exactly a who’s who of widely held stocks, but several top-rated growth names are setting up in bases. Perhaps the most compelling one for a weekly option play is Lululemon Athletica (LULU). It reports Wednesday before the open, and its chart currently shows a buy point of 69.83. If the stock is still…

A dull day in the market failed to produce any notable breakouts. Two that tried and might yet succeed are J.M. Smucker (SJM) and Marsh & McLennan (MMC). Both tiptoed to new highs, couldn't quite clear the bar and did so on light trade. Sometimes, a breakout starts small, then accelerates in big volume once it gets a ways past…

McCormick (MKC) agreed to acquire Reckitt Benckiser Group's food business for $4.2 billion, adding French's mustard and Frank's RedHot sauce to its lineup of spices and seasonings.XThe deal brings a stable of well-known condiments to Sparks, Maryland-based McCormick. For Reckitt Benckiser, unloading the products continues an overhaul that began with an expansion into baby formula through the British company's acquisition of Mead Johnson Nutrition Co. for $16.6 billion.The transaction price equates to 20 times the division's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, "which feels to us like a very high price for a U.S.-oriented ambient food business," James Edwardes Jones, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets, wrote in a note. He expects the transaction to dilute RB's earnings per share by about 1%.The deal comes as speculation swirls about the next round of consolidation in the packaged-food business. In February, Kraft Heinz (KHC) was spurned in a blockbuster bid to take over Unilever (UL), the British-Dutch maker of Hellmann's mayonnaise and Knorr soup. In the aftermath, Unilever was cited by analysts as a possible bidder for the Reckitt business.Nestle SA, the world's largest food company, is also shaking up its portfolio. Under activist pressure to improve results, it's considering selling its U.S. candy operations. Investor Nelson Peltz's Trian Fund Management this week set its sights on Procter & Gamble (PG), the U.S. giant that competes with Unilever in personal care.Led by Chief Executive Officer Rakesh Kapoor, Reckitt said it was looking to unload its food business in April, when the Slough, England-based company described the division as "non-core." With 411 million pounds ($536 million) in sales last year, French's Foods accounted for 4% of Reckitt's total revenue.French's and Frank's RedHot will become McCormick's second- and third-largest brands, respectively, CEO Lawrence E. Kurzius said in a statement late Tuesday. McCormick's pro forma 2017 annual net sales are expected to be approximately $5 billion, with significant margin growth, according to the statement.In acquiring Reckitt's food business, McCormick faced a large group of potential rivals. Bloomberg reported in May that the sale was expected to draw interest from Post Holdings (POST) and Conagra Brands (CAG). Other possible bidders included JM Smucker (SJM), Campbell Soup (CPB), Pinnacle Foods (PF) and Ajinomoto, people familiar with the situation said at the time.In addition to selling yellow mustard and hot sauce, the division makes ketchup, onion flavorings and other products. Hot sauce will continue to see robust growth, with opportunities for expansion, McCormick said. The company said it plans to expand the global presence of Frank's RedHot and French's products, whose sales are now concentrated in the U.S.McCormick dates to 1889, when founder Willoughby McCormick began selling flavors and extracts door to door. The company went after another U.K. business in 2016, when it considered buying Premier Foods. But the suitor walked away from takeover talks in April of that year, saying that Premier was demanding too high a price. McCormick's Kurzius said at the time that Premier was just one of the company's M&A ideas.Credit Suisse Group AG is serving as the financial adviser to McCormick on the RB Foods transaction, and Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton LLP is legal counsel. Morgan Stanley acted as lead financial adviser to Reckitt and the company also received advice from Robey Warshaw.The deal is expected to be completed in the third or fourth quarter of McCormick's fiscal 2017, pending regulatory approvals. McCormick plans to fund the deal with a combination of equity and debt, and said it has obtained committed bridge financing.

When it comes to mature markets, it doesn’t get much more mature than breakfast cereal, which was first introduced in the U.S. during the Civil War.That kind of mileage makes it difficult for leading cereal makers such as Post Holdings (POST) -- which traces its history to 1895 -- to find growth through the kinds of disruptive, gee-whiz advances you’ll find in other sectors of the economy. There’s only so many flavors you can pull out of cereal grains after more than a century of trying, and only so many ways to package and market them.So Post has looked for growth via acquisitions into different product lines. Since being spun off by Ralcorp in February 2012, the company has made nine buyouts. You can expect Post to keep scouting deals in coming months.“We believe we are quite well positioned with the considerable amount of cash on hand approaching $900 million,” Chief Financial Officer Jeff Zadoks said on the company's recent fiscal-first-quarter conference call with analysts. “We’ve got considerable secured debt capacity (and) a very rich pipeline of opportunities. I think we are going to have plenty of opportunities on the M&A front.”Acquisitions have helped Post grow its top line nearly 400% over the last four years — from $959 million in annual revenue in 2012 to $4.6 billion last year.Some have helped Post expand its traditional lineup of cereal brands. But the company also has moved into other product areas like pasta, protein bars, dried fruits, nuts, eggs, sports nutrition supplements and peanut butter. Among the company’s acquired brands: PowerBar, Attune Foods, Dakota Growers Pasta, American Blanching and Mom Brands.Post’s latest buyout came in October, when it spent $90 million to acquire Willamette Egg Farms, a producer, processor and wholesale distributor of eggs and egg products in the Northwest. The Willamette business is expected to add $80 million a year in net sales to Post and around $15 million a year in earnings before various adjustments, or EBITDA.Several different businesses fall under the Post corporate umbrella. The Post Foods business includes ready-to-eat cereal brands such as Grape Nuts, Post Raisin Bran and Pebbles. Mom Brands is geared more toward hot and value-priced cereals.Brands in the Michael Foods Group include Simply Potatoes hash browns, Dakota Growers pasta and All Whites liquid egg whites. The Active Nutrition segment features the PowerBar, Premier Nutrition and Dymatize Nutrition brands. Post also has a Private Brands group that includes Golden Boy peanut butter and nuts, as well as Attune Foods, which is heavy on organic and non-GMO granolas, cereals and snacks.Michael Foods is the biggest segment by sales, accounting for just less than half of the total. Post Foods contributes about one-third of sales, with the rest fairly evenly split between Active Nutrition and Private Brands. All of the segments saw declines in comparable sales during the first quarter.Post had a mixed performance during the quarter, which ended in December. The company logged adjusted earnings of 52 cents a share. That reversed a loss of $1.15 per share from the previous year and came in well above consensus estimates for 25 cents.But sales, which grew 16% to $1.25 billion, came in slightly below views. The gain was driven by Mom Brands, which Post acquired last year for about $1 billion. On a comparable basis that excludes the contribution of acquired brands, Post’s net sales declined 4.2% from the prior year.Still, the company’s share price hit a record high of 72.64 on March 3. The stock has also been helped by volatility in the broader market, which tends to push investors to the relative safety of the food business. In addition to Post, other food stocks that have set new highs in recent weeks include Tyson Foods (TSN), Sysco (SYY), Campbell Soup (CPB) and J.M. Smucker (SJM).“Underlying sales were negatively affected by the volume declines in the egg business, as well as the company’s transition in its Dymatize business to an outsourced production model following the closure of its manufacturing facility in the quarter,” Stifel analyst Christopher Growe noted in a first-quarter earnings report.On the upside, Post’s EBITDA for the quarter came in at $236 million, ahead of estimates. Post also raised its fiscal 2016 EBITDA guidance to a range of $810 million to $840 million from prior guidance of $780 million to $820 million.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Post to log full-year earnings of $1.61 a share, up from 62 cents in fiscal 2015. Earnings are seen rising another 30% to $2.09 in fiscal 2017.“The company noted that this new guidance range incorporates incremental investments (approximately $25 million) related to incremental marketing spending and achieving synergies from the Mom Brands acquisition,” Growe said.During the first-quarter conference call, Chief Executive Robert Vitale mentioned a couple of macro trends that work in his company’s favor. One is low energy prices tied to cheap oil, which helps keep manufacturing costs down.Another is the company’s low exposure to volatile international markets. Post gets less than 10% of its sales from outside the U.S., and most of that comes from Canada.“While this domestic profile is a challenge in delivering volume growth, it also provides a safe haven from recent currency headwinds,” Vitale said.

Eighty-year old companies that specialize in meat production aren’t usually looked upon as growth stocks, but Tyson Foods (TSN) aims to position itself as one anyway.The world’s largest processor and marketer of chicken, beef and pork plans to do so by putting more focus on branded products rather than commodities such as fresh poultry.Its ultimate goal? To become the "leading branded protein company in the world," RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer noted in a recent report."Tyson continues to position itself as a growth company with advantaged brands within advantaged categories," Palmer said.Those categories include high-margin, "value-added" products such as marinated and breaded poultry; prepared foods, including what it calls its “Core 9” packaged brands like Jimmy Dean sausage and Hillshire Farms lunch meat; and antibiotic and gluten-free chicken.During the recent Consumer Analyst Group of New York conference in Boca Raton, Fla., Tyson officials said 85% of the company’s chicken business consists of poultry that is more than just raw meat."This further differentiates (Tyson) from its more commodity-oriented peers," Palmer noted.Tyson Chief Executive Donald Smith echoed that point on a fiscal first-quarter conference call with analysts."I believe we've demonstrated separation from the commodity players in large part due to the disproportionately high mix of value-added products in our portfolio as well as the production flexibility created with our buy vs. grow strategy, which also reduces commodity exposure," Smith said. The "buy vs. grow" strategy refers to Tyson’s decision to purchase some of its chickens from other facilities and reduce the number of chickens it grows itself.Tyson officials have made no secret of their desire to change the way investors view the company. As JPMorgan analyst Ken Goldman pointed out in a recent note, the first two words of Tyson’s presentation at the consumer group event were "different company.""Tyson remains firmly (and understandably) committed to convincing investors that it is a different company than it used to be," Goldman noted. "The primary reason for the difference continues to be Tyson’s emphasis -- both in reality and perception -- on branded food rather than commodity protein."One difference between branded food and commodity meat items is that the former carries higher prices and margins, Goldman says. Tyson’s Core 9 brands carry "an 11% average premium over the category average."Tyson also spent a lot of time talking about revenue growth during the consumer group event. That stood in contrast to other food companies, such as General Mills (GIS) and Nabisco parent Mondelez International (MDLZ), which mainly focused on cost-cutting."These companies spent much, maybe most, of their time today talking about costs, whereas the opposite was true for Tyson," Goldman noted. "It helps to have a category (meat/protein) growing at a better-than-average pace, as well as a category that responds well to mix- and margin-accretive innovation today."There appears to be plenty of demand for Tyson’s meat products. Palmer cited Tyson research showing that 54% of U.S. consumers want to increase the amount of protein in their diets.Worldwide, long-term demand for protein is expected to increase more than 60% from current levels due to population growth and the emergence of a global middle class that can afford to buy more meat products.Favorable industry trends, combined with investor optimism over the food sector in general, have helped push Tyson’s stock price up more than 40% since Nov. 20. Its shares set a record high of 64.63 on Feb. 23 — the sixth straight session they reached a new high.Other large-cap food companies that have set new highs this month include Sysco (SYY), Campbell Soup (CPB) and J.M. Smucker (SJM).One reason for the recent stock gains is the defensive nature of the food business. When stock markets are volatile, many investors flock to consumer staples such as food. Companies in this industry aren’t as vulnerable to wide swings in performance and value and also tend to pay regular dividends. Some food companies also have benefited from cheap gas prices, which lower transportation costs.Meanwhile, Tyson has gotten a lift from falling food costs. Excessive supplies of cattle feed such as corn and soybeans have lowered production prices of beef, poultry and pork. Lower costs were one reason Tyson raised its full-year earnings forecast earlier this month to a range of $3.85 to $3.95 a share from prior guidance of $3.50 to $3.65.The company also recently reiterated its goal of 10%-or-better annual earnings-per-share growth in coming years, and suggested that its long-term margin goals might be conservative.“We would not be surprised if before the fiscal year ended, Tyson raised its long-term chicken margin to maybe 8% to 10% from 7% to 9% currently,” Goldman noted.Tyson posted earnings of $1.15 a share for its fiscal first quarter, which ended in December. That was up 49% from the previous year and well above consensus analyst estimates for 89 cents. It was the biggest quarterly EPS gain in nearly two years.On the downside, revenue declined 15% to $9.15 billion -- the first dip since the September 2012 quarter -- partly because of the divestiture of a few noncore businesses. The top-line result fell short of consensus for $10 billion.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Tyson’s full-year earnings to climb 27% this fiscal year and another 7% in fiscal 2017.

No, it ain’t fish eggs. Instead, ROE means return on equity -- or more accurately, return on shareholders' equity.The gauge divides a company’s full-year net income by its shareholders' equity, then multiplies by 100 to get a percentage figure. IBD takes the average equity over the past two years. The result expresses how much profit it can generate for every dollar of net assets. IBD research into past big market winners shows a ratio of 17% or more as positive. Single-digit ratios could be cause for concern.ROE is a rough gauge for how efficiently management is putting capital to use and how its profitability is keeping pace with its growth as a publicly traded company.  As a company's equity grows, so does the challenge to maintain a high ROE. Earnings per share is another measure that weighs in on this question of ownership vs. profitability. But ROE does not take the number of shares into account.Where do you find it? Get a stock quote by using the search box at the top right corner of Investors.com. Under Stock/Company Data, you will find Annual ROE in the Company Fundamentals column. In addition, the minicharts presented with IBD’s Big Cap 20, Your Weekly Review and IBD 50 include ROE.Some companies often borrow debt to invest in new products and services to drive more profit. As a result, companies with high ROE sometimes also have somewhat elevated levels of debt.So as you perform your stock research, look at peer companies and compare their debt and ROE levels. If a target stock has a higher than group average ROE, and its debt is moderately higher, the two could be related.To be sure, a high ROE doesn’t compensate for unhealthy levels of debt. A long-term debt-to-equity ratio of 100% or more is considered high, even in certain industries known for heavy capital spending.If a stock has a low ROE (single digits and/or well below its group average) and very high debt, it could be a cause for concern.There is also a relationship between profit margins and return on equity. In some cases, you might allow for a below-peer ROE, if the company is churning out top-notch annual pretax margins. In general, annual pretax margin of 17% or higher is a sign of fundamental strength. You also want to see if a company's pretax margin is among the best in its industry.The average return on equity among current IBD 50 stocks is 28.4%. At the high end of the scale among companies that have thus far reported 2015 results, Campbell Soup (CPB) shows an unusually strong return on equity of 52.3%.That is well above peers like J.M. Smucker (SJM), with ROE of 7.2%, and even much larger players such as Kellogg (K), General Mills (GIS) and Kraft Heinz (KHC).Campbell’s pretax margins, 13.1% in fiscal 2015, are in line with these other food giants. Its long-term debt-to-equity ratio of 185% is certainly on the high side. It helps boost Campbell's ROE above a company like Smucker, which shows a long-term debt-to-equity ratio of 84%.

This is especially important to companies like Sysco that move a lot of product from one place to another.Meanwhile, companies such as Tyson have gotten a lift from falling food costs. Consumer staple firms offer products that are always in demand, no matter how well the economy is performing. Primary lines of business include food, beverage, tobacco and basic household items.
Many have been on the prowl for acquisitions, too.

One of the more liquid ETFs in the staples space is the SPDR Consumer Staples ETF (XLP). Its current flat base shows a 51.23 buy point. On Wednesday, XLP rose nearly 2% in strong volume but ended just pennies above the buy point.
Top holdings in the ETF in interesting setups include Dow component Coca-Cola (KO). It's not far from its all-time high of 45 as it works on a base with a 43.95 buy point.

Coke owns a stake in Monster Beverage (MNST) and Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR). Coke's initial investment in Keurig wasn't looking too good until Keurig agreed to be taken private earlier this month in a $13.9 billion deal. The 92-a-share buyout price was a huge premium to its price at the time of around 52.

Kimberly-Clark (KMB) has had a good week so far, helped by a Barclays upgrade to buy from neutral and a price target hike to 155 from 121. The stock is finding support at its 10-week moving average for the first time after a breakout over a 118.05 buy point.It's not a particularly glamorous area of the market — maybe even a bit boring — but consumer staple stocks continue to be a nice pocket of leadership, with many in technical setups that could yield further gains.Consumer staple firms offer products that are always in demand, no matter how well the economy is performing. Primary lines of business include food, beverage, tobacco and basic household items.Many have been on the prowl for acquisitions, too.Headed into Thursday, IBD's Food/Beverage sector was perched near the top of IBD's sector rankings, No. 3 out of 33 that IBD tracks. Fruit jam, cooking oil, peanut butter, ice cream toppings and grocery-chain coffee may not sound like zesty growth areas.
But J.M. Smucker (SJM), a company with more than 113 years of know-how in the pantry food business, has quietly produced a history of long-term growth.

Earnings have grown every year since at least fiscal 2002 (ended in April), from $1.52 a share that year to $4.35 in fiscal 2010. That's an annual compounded growth rate of 14%. What's more, there's little volatility in Smucker's profits. IBD gives it a three-year Earnings Stability factor of 3 on a scale of 1 (most stable) to 99 (most volatile).

One key to the Orrville, Ohio-based firm's success lies in coffee. Acquiring the Folgers brand helped boost total sales 49% to $3.76 billion in fiscal 2009. That business includes Millstone and Dunkin' Donuts-branded bagged coffee.
Back in 2009, Smucker said the Folgers buy helped increase overall gross margin. In fact, margins have continued to improve. Pretax margin rose to 16.9% in fiscal 2010 from 12.7% a year earlier.

In May, Smucker completed the $360 million buy of Miami-based Rowland Coffee Roasters, which makes espresso and caters to Hispanic customers in the Northeast and Florida with its Cafe Bustelo and Cafe Pilon brands. Sales totaled $110 million in 2010.
Smucker announced in May a second hike in coffee prices for 2011.
Earnings per share have grown at double-digit rates in 10 of the past 11 quarters. Sales rose 9% in the quarter ended in January, the biggest increase in five quarters.

Smucker will announce Q4 results June 9. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters see earnings flat vs. year-ago levels at 99 cents a share despite an expected 9% jump in sales. Profit is seen rising 10% to $4.77 a share in fiscal 2011 and 8% to $5.13 in fiscal 2012.
The company paid a 44-cents-a-share dividend to shareholders Wednesday, equal to an annualized yield of 2.2%.

In the week ended Feb. 18, the stock barreled out of a shallow base with a 66.38 buy point. Shares have powered to new highs in recent weeks and have risen about 20% from the proper entry point.Fruit jam, cooking oil, peanut butter, ice cream toppings and grocery-chain coffee may not sound like zesty growth areas.But J.M. That's an annual compounded growth rate of 14%. What's more, there's little volatility in Smucker's profits. Hormel Foods (HRL) reported fiscal first-quarter earnings that topped analyst estimates and raised its full-year earnings guidance Thursday.

The maker of meat products and processed grocery food said earnings climbed 21% to 69 cents per share, above the 64 cents analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting. Revenue rose nearly 7% to $2.39 billion, but fell short of views for $2.46 billion.
Shares rose nearly 1% in premarket trading on the stock market today.
Profit at the refrigerated foods segment increased 19% and sales were up 1% on increased demand for Hormel pepperoni and party trays.

Its Jennie-O Turkey store segment profit jumped 56% with a 10% increase in sales driven by strong sales of lean ground turkey and rotisserie turkey. But Hormel expects the division to see less favorable commodity meat markets for the rest of the year.
Grocery products profit fell 8% but sales were up 2%.
Hormel raised its full-year EPS outlook to $2.50-$2.60 from an earlier range of $2.45-$2.55. Analysts expect $2.53.
Last week packaged food giant J.M. Smucker (SJM) reported stronger-than-expected Q3 earnings but warned on coffee prices.

Food shares are rallying as news of the Kraft Foods (KRFT) merger with ketchup giant H.J. Heinz is making investors' mouths water.Kraft is surging 41% near noon in the stock market today on the news that Heinz owners 3G Capital and Berkshire Hathaway will buy the cheese and snack maker.Shares of Oreo maker Mondelez International (MDLZ) — a Kraft spinoff — are up 2.6%. Cereal giant General Mills (GIS) shares ticked up 2.4%. Dean Foods (DF) rose 1.9%. J.M. Smucker (SJM) shares 2.3%. ConAgra Foods (CAG) shares edged up 1.4%. Kellogg (K) also climbed 1.4%.Natural food makers Hain Celestial (HAIN) shares rose 2.9% and WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) shares bumped up 1.7%, both hitting new highs.Campbell Soup (CPB) shares essentially remained flat, edging up 0.3%.Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) A-class and Berkshire (BRKB) B-class shares edged lower.Looking further down the road, Mondelez, Pinnacle Foods (PF) and B&G Foods (BG) could potentially benefit from the merger, according to RBC Capital Markets analyst David Palmer.If Kraft moves to sell non-core businesses like frozen foods, Birds Eye parent Pinnacle could be a potential buyer, while B&G might eye Kraft's other non-core brands, said Palmer in a note.And Palmer speculates that Mondelez could be the next big acquisition target.According to a recent PwC report, merger deals may be key in streamlining increasingly large portfolios."M&A is likely to become increasingly important, not just in growing food companies, but in streamlining and focusing them," it said.Other recent food mergers include Tyson Foods' (TSN) acquisition of Hillshire Brands and General Mills' buyout of Annie's.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.RELATED:3G Capital, Berkshire To Buy Kraft, Merge With Heinz.
Las Vegas Sands lost the lead in market share to Hong Kong-based SJM Holdings, one of the six casino companies licensed to operate the 35 casino resorts in the world's most popular gambling hotspot.
SJM, operator of the Grand Lisboa, Casino Babylon and 16 other casinos, had about 22.6% of Macau's gross gaming revenue in November, various reports said, citing Macau gambling commission figures.
Sands Macau — a unit of Las Vegas Sands (LVS), the world's largest casino company — saw revenue decline 4% on a year-over-year basis, giving it a roughly 22.5% share.
But Sands Cotai Central, the company's new $4 billion casino on Macau's popular Cotai peninsula, continued to outgrow the market, according to Wells Fargo analyst Cameron McKnight.

Hong Kong-listed Galaxy Entertainment had a market share of 21.5%. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) had 9%. MGM China, a unit of MGM Resorts International (MGM), had 11%, and Hong Kong-based Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) had 13.4%.
Las Vegas Sands stock was down fractionally on the stock market today. Wynn and Melco Crown shares were up less than 1%, while MGM fell less than 1% on Tuesday.
The market-share shift comes as Macau's overall gambling revenue continues to shrink. In November, according to government figures, total revenue dropped nearly 20% to $3.94 billion.

"We believe China policy settings are negatively affecting growth, specifically: (1) visa restrictions (on tourists from inland China to the Macau special administrative district), (2) the anticorruption drive, (3) a pullback in credit and (4) a soft housing market," wrote Wells Fargo's McKnight in a report Tuesday. "We remain on the sidelines as uncertainty remains high."
In November, total "mass" market revenue — middle-class tourists — fell 13% vs. a year earlier in Macau, and the volume of junkets plunged 31%, McKnight said.

So-called junket operators bring gamblers to Macau, especially affluent "VIP"-category high rollers, often lending them money to get around local restrictions on how much cash can be brought into Macau.
The Chinese government has cracked down on the lending practice as part of a broad "anticorruption" campaign, arresting several junket operators earlier this year on charges of money laundering.
VIP revenue fell 24% for the month, McKnight said.

Folgers ownerJ.M. Smucker's (SJM) sales fell during the second quarter of its fiscal 2015, in part a reflection of the higher coffee prices brought on by Brazil's near-yearlong drought.

The coffee, peanut butter and jelly maker, whose brands include Jif and Pillsbury, earned $1.53 a share for the quarter, up a penny from last year and in line with analyst forecasts. Adjusted sales fell 5% from a year ago to $1.479 billion, below estimates for $1.492 billion. The company stood by the fiscal year guidance it issued last week, holding to EPS of $5.45-$5.65. Analysts expect $5.55. Smucker expects a net-sales decline of 1% from its fiscal 2014, which ended April 30.
Shares fell 0.3% to 101.66 on the stock market today.

U.S. retail coffee net sales fell 10% from Q2 2014. Volume in the segment overall declined 18%, led by a 20% volume drop in Folgers. In its earnings release, the company cited higher prices, stronger competition, lower promotional spending and "reduced promotional effectiveness" as reasons.
Brazil is the world's largest coffee supplier and makes more than a third of the world's coffee, including for brands such as Folgers.

"Our second quarter fell short of expectations primarily driven by our coffee business," CEO Richard Smucker said in the company's earnings release. But he said that "the balance of our businesses performed well, led by the Jif, Crisco, and Smucker's brands."
U.S. retail consumer foods profit rose 17% from the year-earlier quarter, but net sales declined 1%.

"Overall lower commodity costs, primarily for peanuts and oils, were partially offset by lower net price realization and drove the segment profit increase," the company said of consumer foods business.
Net sales in the International, Foodservice, and Natural Foods unit fell 2%.

However, net sales for K-Cups used in Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) Keurig brewers rose 12% from the year-earlier quarter. Shares of Keurig closed down 2%, then edged lower in late trading after reporting better-than-expected earnings.Folgers ownerJ.M. With the Keurig 2.0 set to debut this fall, expectations are running high that Keurig Green Mountain's (GMCR) 2014-15 earnings and revenue will get a stiff jolt.
Argus Research upgraded the company to buy from hold and set a price target of 140, predicting K-Cup and brewer sales will helped drive 10% revenue growth in fiscal 2014.
That's higher than the 7.8% growth that analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are projecting, though it would be slower than 2013's 12.9% improvement.
The new $189 Keurig 2.0 can brew a 28-ounce pot of joe using the new K-Carafe pack as well as an individual cup using the regular K-Cup coffee packets.
Shares were up 4% in the stock market today after touching a record high earlier.

But last week, Buckingham Research downgraded its rating on the company to neutral from buy on concerns over rising costs and market penetration, and BTIG recently initiated coverage with a neutral rating.

Shares of Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and other top casinos fell for a third straight session amid conflicting reports Monday about gambling hotspot Macau.
SSome analysts had earlier forecast a short-term decline in Macau after the government cracked down on lenders in China's gaming enclave
Gamblers often borrow money to get around restrictions on how much cash they can bring into the the special administrative district across the strait from Hong Kong.
Chinese officials say some lenders engage in illegal money laundering.

Sterne Agee analyst David Bain said in a report channel checks indicated that Macau's gross gaming revenue, or GGR, was up about 5% so far for June, year over year, to an annualized rate of $3.9 billion.

"This morning, there were initial reports that the first nine days of GGR amounted to 7.8 billion Macau pacatas ($980 million), which would have shown a slower than expected start to June (-4%). Those reports were incorrect," Bain said in his report.
"Our June year-over-year GGR outlook is between -2% and +3%. Recall that we expect some GGR head winds from the World Cup," which began June 12 in Brazil and will likely draw tourists away, he said.
Wells Fargo Cameron McKnight was also moderately downbeat.

"Based on (channel) checks through June 8, we estimate June Macau gaming revenue growth is trending between 1%-5% (higher) year over year, vs. our June estimate of 6.5%," even though that period included two weekends when more people visit Macau, McKnight said.

He remains positive about Macau's long-term prospects. However, "2014 could be choppy due to a potential slowdown in VIP driven by decelerating credit growth and a softer macroenvironment. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) remains our top pick for 2014 given its strong mass market" position. Mass market refers to middle-class tourists from inland China and other countries.

FBR Capital Markets said the crackdown, tighter restrictions on visas for people visiting the city and a recent smoking ban are likely to keep gamblers away. FBR analyst Jake Fuller expects Macau gambling revenue to grow about 10% this quarter, below consensus. He kept market perform ratings on Las Vegas Sands and Wynn and an outperform rating on MGM Resorts International (MGM), a third Vegas casino with Macau operations.

Deutsche Bank cut its 2014 full-year Macau gross gaming revenue forecast from 15% to 12%. It also downgraded Wynn Macau and SJM Holdings — a Hong Kong-based casino that operates in Macau and trades on the Hong Kong exchange — to hold from buy. The bank lowered its price targets on Wynn, Sands, MGM and Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), a Hong Kong-based Macau casino operator that trades on the NYSE.

Morgan Stanley said in its report there may be a quarterly decline in earnings this quarter, the first since the fourth quarter 2009. The bank projected year-to-year VIP gambling revenue could fall 7% "due to fewer weekend days and potential distraction from the World Cup starting June 12."
Shares of Wynn Resorts fell nearly 3% on the stock market today.
Sands and MGM Resorts fell more than 2%, while Melco Crown skidded nearly 6%.
Caesars Entertainment (CZR), which doesn't own casinos in Macau but is the largest U.S. casino operator, climbed 2%.

International Game Technology (IGT), a maker of computerized slots and other casino gaming gear, shot up more than 14% Monday after Reuters reported that IGT is mulling a sale of the company. Casino companies and private equity firms reportedly are interested.

Demand for everyday-use products created by operators in the Consumer Staples space doesn’t tend to fluctuate a lot, but it is nevertheless exposed to macroeconomic forces at the margins. As such, the outlook for this space perks up as the outlook for the U.S. and global economy improves.The outlook for the U.S. economy has been favorable for the last several years, with the recent tax legislation expected to add to the longevity of the current U.S. expansion cycle. In addition to the indirect benefits to Consumer Staples companies from the tax cuts, these companies also stand to benefit directly from the legislation, as reflected in the improving earnings outlook for many companies. That said, Consumer Staples operators tend to be global in their operations and as such don’t benefit to the same extent from U.S. tax law changes as the more domestic companies. With growth hard to come by for companies in this mature space, Consumer Staples players have to remain focused on squeezing more out of their operations and coming out with revenue-boosting initiatives, which mainly include efforts to keep pace with the changing consumer patterns.On that note, let’s delve deeper in some of the major growth-driving strategies of the space.Strengthening Product Portfolio via Strategic Alliances, Buyouts Consumer staples companies are regularly undertaking both domestic and international acquisitions to expand their product lines and gain access to new markets. Some of these are also forming partnerships, mostly with larger and better-known companies, to strengthen their distribution networks, diversify portfolios, expand their reach and enhance market positioning. Notably, leveraging each other’s efficiencies creates significant synergies for companies that go for M&A activities.Mergers of Tyson Foods (TSN  -  Free Report) with packaged meat producer The Hillshire Brands (in August 2014); tobacco giants Reynolds American and Lorillard (in June 2015); food giants Kraft Foods Group, Inc. KHC and H.J. Heinz Company (in July 2015) and consumer goods companies Newell Brands (NWL  -  Free Report) and Jarden (in 2016) were the most talked about deals. Belgium-based brewer Anheuser Busch InBev’s BUD buyout of SABMiller in October 2016 also created a buzz in the beverage industry. Apart from this, Molson Coors (TAP  -  Free Report) acquired SABMiller plc’s 58% stake in MillerCoors, which made the former the third-largest brewer in the world, after Anheuser-Busch InBev and Heineken.Cost Cutting and Restructuring InitiativesMost consumer staples companies are implementing cost-reduction initiatives to boost profits. In the latter half of 2017, Tyson Foods announced a Financial Fitness Program, with the objectives of enhancing operating efficiency, reducing overheads and fuelling bottom-line performance. Colgate CL has also been benefiting from its Global Growth and Efficiency Program, which focuses on reducing structural costs in order to improve gross and operating profit, standardizing processes to improve the decision-making procedure and enhance its market share worldwide.Additionally, Sysco’s (SYY  -  Free Report) core strategies for 2020 include plans to optimize business and achieving operational efficacy. We also commend Kimberly Clark’s KMB 2018 Global Restructuring & Focus on Reducing Costs Everywhere (FORCE) programs, which are expected to generate cost savings of more than $2 billion over the next four years. Companies like McCormick MKC, Coca-Cola KO, Molson Coors, Mondelez International MDLZ, Smucker (SJM  -  Free Report), Kellogg K and many others have also been benefiting from significant cost savings and restructuring initiatives to boost earnings.Focus on InnovationInnovation remains the guiding principle of consumer staples companies as it enables them to enhance brand appeal through product differentiation and capture market share across all regions and categories. Thus, companies put a lot of thrust on innovation to upgrade their brands and create differentiated value propositions. Notably, constant innovations supported by efficient marketing are essential for consumer staples companies to stay ahead of competition.As evidence, novelty has been a driving force for consumer product giants like The Procter & Gamble Co. (PG  -  Free Report) and Colgate-Palmolive, and cosmetic majors like Estee Lauder EL. These companies constantly come up with new products that suit changing consumer trends, to tap demand and boost revenues. Also, major food companies like Smucker and Campbell Soup CPB, alcohol stocks like Brown-Forman BF.B and Constellation Brands (STZ  -  Free Report), and even tobacco players like Altria (MO  -  Free Report) and Phillip Morris (PM  -  Free Report) have been adding new products to gain competitive edge and augment market share.Exiting Underperforming Units to Enhance OperationsApart from growing their businesses through buyouts, companies also remain focused on improving their product portfolios through divestitures. Offloading underperforming operations enables the companies to concentrate on the core and profitable areas.For example, as part of its strategic business review following its merger with Jarden, Newell Brands announced plans to sell nearly 10% of its current portfolio, including a major chunk of its Tools segment. This highlights the company’s focus on simplifying its operating structure, alongside highlighting its commitment toward making prudent investments in areas with higher growth potential. Similarly, Unilever (UL  -  Free Report) announced plans to sell its shrinking Spreads business to KKR (in December 2017) to shift concentration on fast-growing products.Adopting E-Commerce Mantra: The Need of the HourWith technology having advanced by leaps and bounds, online shopping has become the order of the day. Thanks to various mobile apps and dot.com business lines, shopping for anything is literally on consumers’ finger-tips. Consumers’ rapid shift to e-marketplace has compelled companies to adopt the e-commerce mantra. Companies like United Naturals (UNFI  -  Free Report), SUPERVALU (SVU  -  Free Report), Campbell Soup and Estee Lauder among others, are striving to enhance e-commerce space, through investments in technology and infrastructure.Driven by these efforts, United Natural Foods’ e-commerce sales jumped almost 28.9% in the second quarter. As for SUPERVALU, the company’s contract with Instacart, along with endeavors to upgrade website and mobile applications underscore its knack to enhance consumer shopping experiences.Transition to Health and Wellness ProductsAs consumer preference is the life blood of Consumer Staples, companies have to adapt to evolving trends to stay strong in the industry. A key trend over the last few years has been the desire for natural and organic products, prompting many players in the space to come out with health and wellness offerings. This is the case with almost all industries in the sector.Apart from this, tobacco companies like Altria and Reynolds American are also adapting to the evolving needs of consumers and have resorted to less harmful alternatives like electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes). To cater to changing consumer preference, Philip Morris launched the much talked about IQOS, a smokeless cigarette in November 2014, aiming to lead the tobacco industry’s push into reduced-risk products. IQOS is anticipated to boost market share and offset declining volumes in traditional cigarette business over the long term.Additionally, rising consumer awareness regarding the harmful impact of toxic chemicals has been driving the market share for organic personal care products too. Consequently, players like Unilever are making solid progress in the natural and organic products category. This is evident from its deal to buy Schmidt’s Naturals that specializes in personal care products such as deodorants, toothpaste and bar soaps. Clearly, these robust efforts are expected to boost the companies’ top line in the future.Clearly, the consumer staples space offers plenty of reasons to be optimistic about it over the long term. So how about investing in the space right now?Check out our latest Consumer Staples Outlook here for more on the current state of affairs in this market from an earnings perspective, and how the trend is looking for this important sector of the economy now.More Stock News: This Is Bigger than the iPhone!It could become the mother of all technological revolutions. In a market where pet nutrition is rapidly picking pace, The J. M. Smucker Company (SJM  -  Free Report) has struck the right chord with its latest move to acquire Ainsworth Pet Nutrition, LLC. Additionally, the company revealed intentions to explore prudent choices for its U.S. baking category, which includes the possibility of a divestiture. Let’s take a closer look at these announcements and see what it means for the company.Ainsworth AcquisitionPer the terms of the deal, Smucker will acquire pet foods provider Ainsworth from L Catterton, a renowned private equity company, in a transaction worth approximately $1.9 billion. The amount includes estimated tax benefit of approximately $200 million. The company projects annual synergies of close to $55 million during the first three years. Also, post completion of the deal, the new business will add about $800 million in the first year. Subject to certain conditions, the transaction is expected to close during the fiscal year beginning on May 1, 2018.Pet Food Gaining TractionThe pet food category has lately delivered growth, courtesy of consumers’ becoming increasingly conscious about the health and wellness of their pets. In fact, the pet food and snacks category generate sales of more than $30 billion annually and counts amongst the fastest growing segments in the nation’s food and beverages market. The company’s effort to tap into this fast-growing arena, with the Ainsworth buyout, is expected to bolster its pet business. Additionally, the buyout will add the well-known Rachael Ray Nutrish brand to Smucker’s pet food portfolio. Incidentally, the Rachael Ray brand accounts for close to two-thirds of Ainsworth's sales. Apart from Smucker, General Mills Inc. (GIS  -  Free Report) has been striving to expand in this category and entered into an agreement to acquire Blue Buffalo Pet Products, Inc.  in February.Well, this is not the first time that J.M. Smucker has undertaken strategic efforts to strengthen its footing in pet foods. In 2015, it acquired Big Heart Pet Brand that added iconic brands such as Meow Mix and Kibbles 'n Bits. The buyout has been bolstering the company’s pet food business. Incidentally, net sales in the company’s U.S. Retail Pet Foods category inched up 2% during the third quarter of fiscal 2018, owing to improved volume/mix. These were primarily related to the Nature's Recipe brand and the company’s pet snacks portfolio. With the inclusion of Ainsworth, we expect Smucker to expand further in this category.Review of Baking BusinessJ.M. Smucker is also reviewing strategic options for its U.S. baking business, including a possible divestiture. The review process is expected to be completed by the end of the first quarter of fiscal 2019. The company’s baking business encompasses renowned brands such as Pillsbury and Hungry Jack amongst others. The business, which falls under the U.S. Retail Consumer Foods segment, is expected to generate sales of approximately $370 million for the fiscal year ended in April, 2018. The review process forms part of the company’s restructuring efforts to focus more upon its pet products, coffee, snacks and other food items.  Wrapping it UpWell, the food industry has been grappling with stiff competition and shifting consumer preferences. Despite these headwinds, industry players like J.M. Smucker and United Natural Foods (UNFI  -  Free Report) are resorting to strategic tie-ups and other growth initiatives to thrive and sustain. J.M. Smucker actively pursues strategic acquisitions both in the United States as well as overseas. Further, the growing popularity of certain brands has encouraged the company to undertake innovations. Moreover, cost-saving initiatives have enabled the company in undertaking investments.Indeed, such dedicated endeavors are likely to keep this Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) company as investors’ favorite. Markedly, the stock has advanced 18.7% in the past six months, versus the industry’s decline of 5.6%.You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.Today's Stocks from Zacks' Hottest StrategiesIt's hard to believe, even for us at Zacks.
